name: One Way Heroics
description: Across all dimensions, the only constant is Darkness! A procedurally generated RPG-roguelike journey across the multiverse! In One Way Heroics, you take on the role of an intrepid adventurer who must travel across the land and face the Demon Lord before a mysterious darkness engulfs everything.
minimum_requirements: OS: 2000, XP, Vista, 7, 8, 8.1, 10 Processor: Pentium III 1.0 GHz or better Memory: 256 MB RAM Graphics: 800x600 resolution or higher DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 50 MB available space

reviews.review_text: Being a big fan of Anime, turn based RPG's and rogue-like games, I was very curious with One Way Heroics, having an accessible price, I decided to risk buying it and check it out, truth be told I would never thought I'd love this game so much as I do, it completely caught me by surprise.  The mechanics are quite simple, you're forced to go eastwards in an 8 character string world (that is randomly generated each play-through) in order to avoid a mysterious mist that is covering the planet.   Each decision you take being a dialogue option, attacking, defending, healing, equipping and so on, will be counted as a turn, each turn you do the mist will also do his in parallel so you'll have to make sure to not fall behind or your play-through will be over, so you'll have to have special attention to which decisions or paths you should take, sometimes you'll feel compelled to explore a dungeon and find new items but the mist can prove to be too risky since you'll always have that constant threat looming next to you.   You have different ways of ending one play-through depending of the difficulty and the game mode you're playing, you can achieve victory by killing the demon king, by reaching the end of the world, by killing a secret boss and so on, in order to spice it up the developers decided to make some random events, cities and quests to make the game more interesting and more unique in each play-through.  The game UI is quite simple and it does well its job, the game soundtracks are fun and memorable but they can get a bit repetitive after a while, the art style ain't phenomenal by any means but overall it has an interesting and unique presentation to it.  The game is very affordable and full of content, it has great replay value, so I'd like to recommend to all of you who is thinking about getting this underrated gem, you'll love it!

Sold everything I had to a poor merchant for silvers, made him get mauled by a bear, took the stuff he dropped, walked away with 50,000 silvers and all my stuff and extra, rinsed and repeated with every town I come upon. Got 999.999 silvers and became the richest man in the world where money doesn't matter anymore because everyone is dying. put on a bracelet that bloody merchant lying on the ground had, sacrificing half my stats but getting 3x experience, after 10 days I rose to level 649 and became an all powerful God. One-hit killed everyone I came across by punching it in the face. True story.  Actual Review of the Game: Totally worth the price when it goes on sale like the Steam Summer Sale and the Winter Exploration Sale where it gets to less than a buck. There's 8 classes (only a couple in the beginning), but 24 sprites to choose fun. The worlds are randomly generated and filled with a lot of content that take a long time to go through, finding almost a new thing everytime. After a long time, my brother and I went through every NPC, companion, items, and weapons you could go through, but it never got boring because it's so different (yet the same) every time! I just recently got the DLC One Way Heroics Plus and it has about 3x the content now comparing it to the original, much more aesthetics and features that got me into it again. The music that is seen throughout the different biomes, towns, and bosses is also really good enough that I put them on my phone because you can find them online for free. Its just awesome overall.  I r8 8/8 m8 no h8, it gr8

I use Zenura Weave, sacrificing my clothing for power. I go into a town and people judged me, the one that's saving them all, for not wearing anything. I run into the Demon Lord, who is a lonely reject hellbent on killing everyone in the world. Since we both weren't accepted, we ultimately joined forces and ran across the entire world together, allowing everyone of those townsfolk to suffer from the darkness.  All in all, this game is a beautiful story about discrimination, friendship, streaking, punching cute animals, and acceptance.

I'm no expert on roguelikes. But this game at base price costs about as much as a cup of coffee from a mid-market coffee chain. I've played it for twenty hours, and it still feels like I'm scratching the surface; after each run, I feel like I learned something about how the game works, about what it wants from me and how to succeed. It's a good feeling. The game is fair but challenging, and for those of us for whom that isn't enough, offers a highly modular difficulty system (base difficulty plus class plus perks, all of different usefulness) to challenge yourself with. There's incremental progress and upgrades to unlock if you'd rather have a barometer of progress other than your own growing skill at the game, which is difficult to quantify, but grinding for these things isn't really an issue -- classes and perks are pretty cheap, at least for the useful ones, and everything else is bonus stuff.  If you buy the expansion, you're basically getting a game that has double or triple the content of the base game, and also includes a whole bunch of quality of life UI upgrades and balance changes. A lot of the things added are very simple and unobtrusive but satisfying -- things like turning to face the enemies automatically, a little screen to track all of the things you've achieved as each class, more dimensions to facilitate the psuedo-multiplayer. Other additions are bigger -- new classes, new allies, new npcs, new bosses and objectives and missions. While the price of the dlc is triple that of the base game, it's absolutely worth it -- even more so if you can get it on sale. The hours of gameplay/$ ratio is excellent.  It's also in the class of games that are easy to play while doing something else, like holding a skype conversation or queuing for a match in some other game. It takes very little processor power, deals with tab switching quite agreeably, and time stops while you aren't moving.  All in all, I think it's a great way to spend an hour or two between doing other things, and ends up being quite moreish once you've wrapped your head around the basic steps to survival. Then, it's all about the rng and your own wits. Recommended.

Bought this game on a whim when it costed less than a euro during a steam sale. Had I known it was this good, I'd have bought the game at full price on release. One Way Heroics is a roguelike in a more traditional sense of the phrase, while taking massive hints from FTL's style of one-way travel and resource managment.  What's especially surprising is how addictive and fun the online elements of this game are, as there is an option to join a world with multiple people already in it. The special seeded levels that rotate on a daily basis add some serious life to the game as well.

Oh dude, this is just so damn cool!   Great for quick sessions, surprising depth of play, multiple classes, a cool unlock system based on Hero Points for each run, rogue-like (perma-death), a vault for item transfer between plays, cool boss battle, and not too hard for newies to the type to get into. Seriously, A+ and an absolute STEAL at the price.

This game is simply amazing.  You start by choosing a class and up to 5 perks, but you will have to unlock most of these first. It's fun trying different combinations and seeing how they play out.  The map is determined by the seed you choose, you can pick a random one, enter one yourself or choose one of a few daily dimensions that are altered in a special way. The game is rogue-like and turn-based, dying means perma-death. During your run you will explore the map, find loot, kill monsters and other enemies, level up, talk to several NPCs who offer various services, recruit NPCs to help you fight and finish your main quest (which is usually killing a boss).  Every turn the darkness behind you consumes a little bit more of the map, so you have to keep progressing forward and think carefully about if you'll have enough time to explore a dungeon or visit a town. Normally this isn't really a problem, you can easily outrun the slowly-progressing darkness. In case of emergency you can use your Awakening ability up to 5 times, which stops the time for 3 turns so you can get yourself out of trouble.  Usually whenever you die, it is because you weren't careful, you will learn from most deaths. Most of the time there are ways to save yourself, but you just didn't try or think of everything or were too cocky, though of course there are also times when the game really seems to hate you.  There are multiple endings depending on how you beat the game and which NPC you have with you. Moreover when you beat the game you can store some items in your vault, which you can choose to use at the beginning of each run.  Lastly, it's a single-player game, but while playing the game online it will show you details about other players who are in the same dimension and occasionally you will meet ghosts of other fallen players who will drop one of their items and give you experience. Furthermore after clearing a dimension it will show you the characters of everyone who completed it as well.  For the price, especially when it's on sale, it's a steal. I definitely also recommend buying  OWH+  if you already enjoyed the base game, it adds a lot of new content.
Yeah it's pretty good, but if you take out all the good stuff, it's pretty bad.

I paid 86 cents for this on sale, and it's one of the best damn games I've played all year. The concept is clever, and the execution is basically flawless. OWH has more polish and apparent effort put in than a lot of games from big studios. You can pick it up and play without too much investment, but there's more depth than is initially obvious. Repeat plays are encouraged with daily worlds, higher unlockable difficulties, new classes/perks, and lots of secrets and extra endgame content. The graphics, music and translation/humor are also spot on. UUUUUUGH JUST BUY IT

It's a roguelike with pressure ever looming to the left side of the screen, in the form of a shadow engulfing the world. You must travel to the east, hopefully getting stronger along the way, because to the far east, the Demon Lord, who summoned the darkness, awaits.  Key features: - JRPG look and feel - No location transition; everything happens on the overworld map - Shadow pressing you to move on vs stick around longer to explore more of this town/dungeon - Turn-based - JRPG style menu system - Running non-stop, your hero still require sustenance - Items have limited durability - With each death (or victory) you gain hero points, which can be used to purchase more options (and thus more freedom) in future games - Item vault to transfer items to your next characters. Item vault size is expanded by using hero points - Unlockable classes - Unlockable perks - Randomly generated world with a short text-based random seed - Many features in the world which you can explore. (I found some high-end merchants hidden inside a mountain once. Was too slow to get back out). - You can replay a world by entering the seed - Fast paced. You can easily win a game in one sitting - Online events everyday. There are worlds with special rules which you can play in - Multiple difficulty levels can be unlocked - Great attention to details that will make you smile - Steam cards and achievements  This $2.69 will be the best $2.69 you've ever spent.

THIS GAME IS AWESOME!!!!!!   Imagine Final Fantasy (art style), Binding of Isaac (replay value), and Spelunky (random generated world) all mix in one game!  Extremely addictive and tons of replay value.  It's totally worth the price and I totally recommend it to any old school gamer.
By far the best 3.00 investment I've made in a long time. A fourth the price of other games, and already more hours logged.
Nice game , worth up your time to play it . Might be hard for the beginner , but then it went more easier later in time . It also has many character to play with .
Darkness is always in the persuit! good fast paced game for people who like to die alot
This game is very deep and gets more complicated the longer you play.

Very charming roguelike, it is very relaxing, challenging and got personality. Great music, simple but good graphics.  About the gameplay, its very straightforward, you customize your character that should keep moving ahead otherwise the darkness will eventually catch. Many artifacts, many recruitables, many configurations, online mode... Its hard to explain, lets just say that its really fun.

This game is really nice, even if you have to do the same thing over and over the fact that you can generate random maps and that you have to flee the dark wall it make it nice each time, I had a great time trying to unlock everything, and trying to get the best weapon i could save in chest.    I Would defenetly would reccomend this game to all those you doesn't care about graphic and care about the fun time you can have playing a game. This is one of those time i can say i got my money well-spent.

This game is a lot more addictive than I first gave it credit for. The randomly generated worlds are done well for the most part and you gain access to multiple classes that change up your strategy. One Way Heroics looks simplistic and barebones from the outside but I've had a lot of fun gradually unlocking more options to play around with. I'd say there's plenty of content for the money.
Why not?

This game is amazing! You won't get a game this good for just 3 dollars. There's vast amount of contents in the game, and the replayability is very high. Lots of classes, lots of items, new maps with new stuff etc.
Game was awsome, i love this one :D.

One of the most underrated and unique turn-based roguelikes on Steam. There are many elements that are similar to that of more traditional roguelikes, such as slaying monsters, leveling up, and collecting loot. However, unlike any other game in the genre, there's a looming wall of death that draws closer to you ever turn, forcing you to flee to the right. There's little time to stop for breath and allow yourself to heal; if you don't keep moving, the wall will devour you and end your game. You'll stumble across towns and dungeons where you can buy or obtain items, or slay enemies for experience, but even those will soon be engulfed in darkness. As if things couldn't get any worse, every so often the very powerful Demon Lord will spawn and try to end your quest before you become strong enough to kill him. Early on in the game, you'll have no choice but to run away from him, because luckily he'll be forced to retreat after a pre-determined amount of turns. Either way, it's another unique element of the game that you'll be forced to plan around.   Oh, and there's plenty of other rather spiffy features you might not expect in a game this cheap. There's a decent number of rather diverse classes to play, unlockable perks to customize your character, multiple difficulty settings, daily challenges with unique gameplay twist, limited interaction with other players online, selectable world seeds... oh, and you can post the results of your run to Twitter. There's that. But seriously, there's no reason not to try this game. It has plenty of depth and replayability, and it's only a few dollars. If there was anything bad I could say about it, I suppose the graphics could be better? Who cares, it's a roguelike. Half of those are in ASCII anyway. Get on it, yo!

super great oldschool style japanese style roguelike game. unique mechanics, cool online features, great replayability  best value for the few bucks it costs. this is a REAL roguelike-like unlike the other babified dumb games w/ lite elements that come out these days

super great oldschool style japanese style roguelike game. unique mechanics, cool online features, great replayability  best value for the few bucks it costs. this is a REAL roguelike-like unlike the other babified dumb games w/ lite elements that come out these days

Magnificent, amazing, it triggers you to go ..again..and again..and again.. and you hate when you break that ultimate tweaked item. You hate when the darkness did catch you or when you hit into a monster that was wayyy too strong for you..but ..you have to play again.... you cannot stop.. .. Awesome!

I have had so much fun just choosing classes going into randomized generated worlds and seeing how far my perks and class can take me. I sometimes wish there was a survival mode just keep going to see how far you can get.  I love the simplistic feel and nostalgic feel of the gameplay and graphics. There are unlockable classes. Its got great replay value. Exploring class and perks with each adventure gives you the power to challenge your self.

A greata value for the cost, I am getting plenty of enjoyment from this game. Its a highly replayable game which requires learning and strategy to get to the later and more difficult areas. It rolls over loot and allows you to unlock abilities for new starting characters. I say, worth the price. Kudos

Welcome to the world of One Way Heroics. You can play as multiple characters while you travel to the right side of the map at all times for a great darkness follows and swallows the world behind you. Do you have what it takes to manage the up coming challenges and escape the creeping death while facing the dangers ahead?  Starting off the king sends you upon a journey to escape the darkness and find the truth of what is happening to the world, you take the challenge before you and must move and leave behind the castle. Once on the move you must use cunning and skill in a semi turned based, rogue-like, RPG full of challenges. Bosses await your arrival at certain intervals, the randomly generated map will keep you on your toes. Decisions will have you staring at your screen for minutes at a time. Should you use that ability to save your life or keep pushing yourself to the limit for the slim chance of victory.  I expect to be placing alot more time into this gem. It has an excellent amount of difficulty and a very unique type of gameplay with the grid system, in-depth attributes, weapon enchanting, and item management.   I highly recommend this game, thanks for reading.

Iris is qt3.14  Seriously though, this is a cute little time-killer sidescrolling roguelite with a mechanic that forces you to move forward or be swallowed by the encroaching darkness coming from the left side of the screen. Simple mechanic, but effective (should I risk racing for that chest I just spotted near the left or move on?) Very lighthearded, doesn't take itself seriously at all. Pretty satisfying, with solid turn-based grid gameplay and plenty of fun classes and skills to unlock.

Walk in a straight line, attack what-ever you want, die. Wash, rinse repeat. That is how the general gist of this game progresses. There isn't a whole lot of depth to the game, there aren't many weapons, aren't many variations of enemies, no characters you really connect with, the map areas are general generic type fanatasy locales, and no real story line (other than to stop The Darkness) which is stated in the opening 3 seconds of the game. However this game has something going for it... charm.  If that sounds silly just run with it for a moment. There is very little to do, or really unlock that can't be done easily. Unlike the game that drew me to this (Faster Than Light) you can unlock everything in nearly 5 hours, the remainder of the time will be playing with these unlocks. However the goofy commentary from the few NPC's you do find are enough to distract momentarily from the humdrum of walking to your right. That is where this game gets its charm from. The constant breaks in the basic mechanics of the game for a fun, light hearted gab between pixelated characters.  Finding all the secret endings and characters endings will be what make you come back to this. The small morsels of charm that you get are what will make you enjoy coming back to it. However, don't expect to be able to play this for long periods of time. I found that the game is best when played a few run throughs at a time. Any longer than that and the charm kinda wears off and the simplistic nature of the game robs from its potential.  Additional peripheries were pretty decent as well. The music is fun to listen to but after prolonged time periods begins to grate at your ears. The graphics are simple enough and give it a classic RPG feel that allows me to relive the days of early Final Fantasy's. Mechanics are simple and will be picked up with one minute of playing.  Feeling in a good mood today so let's give this game an eeked out 7/10

This game is so good that I really want to make 100% achivement, very challenging ^ ^ *Totally worth it's money. *Awesome music, can listen for hours 'infected village' track!  *Cute art. *I love DL :3  Great game 10/10.   In our life there can be only One Way Heroics..

It's basically a JRPG combined with a roguelike. There's a big amount of content for the price (which is even cheaper if you buy it off of Playism), including varied classes, daily challenges/runs, hidden endings, and more. It's not too difficult for beginners to get into, but hardcore roguelike fans will still find challenge in the harder difficulty modes. It's really addicting to see how far you can get in a few hours, and you can compare how well you're doing against other players on the same seed in real-time (you can even post your wins/losses on Twitter #OneWayHeroics).   Some people might complain about its lack of depth; don't expect a complex turn-based combat system like in  Final Fantasy  or a deeply complicated and engaging story. The real fun in this game is in how easy it is to pick up and play. It's definitely worth the price, and it has way more replay value than most of the games priced at $5 - $10 here.   TL;DR - Probably the most fun, easily accessible Roguelike you'll find on Steam that's under $5.  :)

One Way Heroics is a unique game. While at first it seems a little grindy and nearly as death embracing as Dark Souls underneath this veneer the game sparkles. It has some great classic (cliche if you will) story segments that are randomly generated each time you restart and also it has a slight dry humor to some dialogue whichis quite refreshing. The music is beautiful and suits the game and does not become annoying. Perhaps the most astounding thing is that the creator found that other game creators couldn't meet his system needs so he built his own! (WolfRPG) which is quite a feat. Though it would be hard to integrate some multiplayer DLC or sequel would be a great addition to this title. I highly recommend this since it comes at such a low price!

In addition to the Steam version, I've also logged another 50 hours on One Way Heroics Plus. Even at full price, it's totally worth it, if you're even tangentially into procedurally generated roguelikes.  PROS: Three dollars at full price, and constantly going on sale. Several ways to beat the game. Nearly infinite replay value. OWH+ has already been released on playism, and adds even more depth to the game. Nobody is immune to anything. If it says it works, it will work. No more pesky 'Poison only works on player, but not bosses' nonsense.  CONS: dated graphics Weapons are hard to keep forever (Not that you need them, but you grow attached). Poor scaling for super long runs. There's no setting between 'You slaughter this guy' and 'You die in one hit'

Forced-Sidescroller meets RPG in a game where the world can be generated a hundred different ways.  Good notes: High customization options, good feedback system to help you out, unlockable content makes each run feel like a step forward, replay data is semi-entertaing to watch, and a system with depth to items/combat.  Neutral notes: Well executed 8 bit stlying, faux-multiplayer in which you interact with the dead and recieve semi-selective notes from other players (only available in that day's multiverse world).  Bad notes: Even on full screen the text may still seem a bit small and some world combinations (I've only found 2 and have entered no less than 25 worlds) are less than enjoyable due to constant mountains or being nearly devoid of interactable content(villages/dungeons/chests)  With all of that said, I give this a full recomendation if you enjoy a rogue-like.

Great little Rogue RPG game. I enjoy the one way, pushing you forward and making it more difficult at times than many RPG's where you can easily rank against low level enemies etc. Reasonable range of weapons and enemies, nice music, and the world generation makes the gameplay much less tedious than it would be without. Alot of great features. Sometimes you can come across a Golem or ambush at a low level and get wrecked by it, and a little more customisation wouldn't go amiss, but for £2.29 who can complain! Well worth the money and well worth a try! 8/10 for a low price Rogue style game.

Quite an enjoyable Japanese roguelike that forces you to move forward and die the first few attempts. If you can get over the graphics and you enjoy roguelikes then you should have no problem at all getting your money's worth out of this title.

Absolutely great game with great replayability a) do quick runs when you don't have enought time b) use your 'dimensional vault' to carry over your favorite items c) gain points to get new perks and classes which you can use in future runs  I have so far passed the 400km runs with Swordsman, Knight, Hunter and Adventurer. I have started to search for some info on the net and it looks like you can go up to 2000km with some skill and good gear. I need to test that.  Also competing on the same maps against other players to see who can get the most out of it and regular 'quest' runs make this game even more awesome. I still have a lot to learn about this game, but I already like it a lot.  The only thing I don't like so far is the fact your gear depreciates and breaks and it is not so easy to repair it. I bond with my gear emotionally :-) and it hurts when I loose it :-)

A good game for it's shockingly low price.  A low price and can be played again and again.
An oddly satisfying game... You initially feel like it won't be much, but you get the feeling that 'you can go just a little further next time'.

Really caught me off guard how addicting this game became. I played it for around 2 hours before I realized I was focusing so hard that I was leaning forward into my chair. It offers an almost endless challenge. Would certainly recommend to anyone.

An excellent, well polished, and surprisingly deep lightweight roguelike experience. Easy to play in short bursts or longer sprints and quite enjoyable to a variety of skill levels. If the game looks at all interesting to you, drop the ~$3 and give it a shot.

This game, despite being a little difficult to get the hang of, is good fun. I is a combination between Rouge Legacy, Finaly Fantasy, and Mario (the fact being you can only go forward, never back). The procedurally generated worlds adds to the complexity of the game. If found myself making character sheets of past characters so should i find a weapon that suits them in a run through in which the weapon is useless, i can stick it in the storage and make them the header for the next run. I've also found myself becoming addicted to the worlds i create, wanting to defeat them before I create a new one. To paraphrase, this game is a refreshing bundle of originality, ingenuity, whilst also winking at the games from the Ninetys. In a way, this is a less masochistic 16-bit version of Dark Souls.
It's a really good game and for only a few cents definately worth it!
Fast paced, Frantic and pretty good.

This game is very innovative, and whilst playing I can't help but bring to mind Half Minute Hero as well. If you've played that and enjoyed it, you'll love this. This game is very fast paced, and if somehow you manage to plow your way through it immediately (good luck) you will have only spent 30 minutes on it. However, the game's replay-ability is it's biggest feature. Each victory ends with more loot, more rewards, more knowledge, and more challenging modes to continue playing with. The game is endless hours of fun, and I must say it is well worth the small amount of money it costs. ($3.00 For anything that lasts for hours and hours is a good deal, regardless of what your interests are.)

A brilliant and unexpected mixed-itteration of roguelike/rpg. Go in blind. The game throws a lot of subtle class and humor, along with solid game play, try everything, don't be too afraid, you can't really mess this one up, because the game didn't.  Does almost everything right except maybe the resolution, which can be a problem for steam announcements, as they get in the way of play.   For the price, maybe one of the best cost/playtime ratios of any game out there. Highly recomend to anyone who is a fan of either roguelike or RPG.

Fantastic game! Simple, addicting, and well worth the purchase! And with it being on sale right now it's a steal at the price. Has progress methods like rogue legacy, and that simple snes feel to it. Great way to kill some time :)

I had about a dollar and fifteen cents on my steam wallet and thought that I was only going to be able to get a garbage game when the steam sale came. I was so wrong this game is rather confusing at first, but once you get the hang of it, it's rather interesting. I have almost unlocked all the classes except for the hero class and have barely touched the perks. I know there are people you can get to follow you which I haven't encountered yet not for lack of looking that is. It is a great game and I would say it's worth the price.

This game is the perfect example of a hidden gem. It's not well-known and very cheap, but god damn is it entertaining! So, want a challenging game with a lot of charm and lots of variety? - Play this!
Don't play if you like to backtrack

A really good mini game. Didnt expected that.  Pros:  Cute and somewhat sad story when you die (didnt reach the end yet) Fun gameplay for once in a while when you have nothing to do :D  Cons Its says multiplayer game but even though i can see the players name on the screen, i cant see them on my way !  Fast deaths Frustrating if you are a noob like me x,d
This game is pure brilliance is a small and simple package.
a damn good game definetly worth picking up though it would be insanely hard but its actually not bad if ur good at turn based games :P
The game is amazing. I'll elabore below.  I'll start with the bad things i saw on my first minutes.    Negative

This game is simply amazing, it's something that you can totally use to burn time, explore a vast randomized world where every encounter is different. If you like old school rpg's then this will definitely satisfy you.

This is seriously one of the best fast paced and turn based game i have ever played. You'll discover something new everytime as long as you get far enough. Many classes to fit you. Different difficulties, party members. This game has it all. I would highly recommend it to all those who likes these kind of games.

This game is well work the money. you will get a large amount of game play out of it and even when you get tired of it, it will only be for a few days. the only bad thing i have to say is that it does not explain things as well as it should it kind of just points you in a direction (the direction being left) and says kill the demon king. Even with the game doing this once you get used to it, it will be well worth your money.
For those who like 8-bit era this game can be an option.
Seriously I can play this whole day long. Pretty impressive for a WOLF rpg maker game.
A really simple yet deep gameplay, even comes with surprises and secrets worth playing and recommended for its low cost gives a lot of fun time

AWESOOOOOOOOOOOOME! Get it fot less than a dollar, one of my best rogue-rpg games.  Incredible! Long time ago I want some developers create a old school rpg rogue game! Cool story, easy gaming, random worlds and random items! I like that! If you like kind of RPG games, Old School and adictive games! I reccomend you OWH! Love the gameplay, one of my favorites!

Very hard to get used to the controls for some reason, but once you do the game is amazing, i suggest playing it while watching a walk-through for it so that you can better understand the world you've entered. The game itself isn't inherently hard, but you have so little to work with that it takes getting used to. Warning to new players to stay away from Golems, they have set spawn locations per world and they are nasty with or without an axe (which does more damage to them).  Characters can be unlocked with points rewarded for your progress after each death or by completeing a certain feat. You can use these points to get a vault and add space to said vault. The Vault NPC is in the set spawn for each character. I recommend always keeping a Key of Seals in the Vault if you manage to come across one. Keys of Seals are used on Temples and can give you Holy Artifacts. My first holy artifact was an Axe that crushed everything before me. By the time it had worn down i found another temple and another key of seals, and got a Holy Spear and Holy Chest Armor. Made it the last 80 km to the Demon Loard and killed him with no struggle.   I've only gotten 2.8 hrs of playtime in the time of this review, but i could easily put 200 hours into it. It's cheap for it's value of entertainment, and if you end up in a poor spawn you can always just continue again.   More tips -Always buy from a Chef When/If you reach a town. They seem pricey but in actuality they are cheap and extremely valuable. -This game is about Trade-offs, you may end up choosing things that are detrimental to the world you spawn on. -More expensive is not always better, especially when you do not have a high enough Item-Appraisal to know what you are buying. -Randomly Generated worlds always have their problems, the largest map wrecker in this game is large mountain walls that you have to climb. They take a great deal of turns to climb and eat your stamina, if you find yourself having to climb mountains frequently you will die, and you may want to explore a different route or a new world entirely. -Chests in the water are also death-traps but if you can manage it, they may offer useful loot. -Teleportation Pills will save you from Bandits, Bears, or Golems. -Axes will destroy walls and chests with ease for better dungeon navigation. -Bows and Lances will help you kill your enemies from a distance, very beginner friendly weapons, unless you have no arrows.   Negatives about this game -   The loss of your character after completeing the game is without a doubt a loss, but the ability to save his gear makes up for it, despite the fact it is battered and will probably have to be repaired despite my deep loathing of the brittle debuff.

I have not in a long time played such a roguelike that captures all the difficulty and strategy of Shiren the Wanderer style games, and successfully marries it with unique quirks of its own. This title is one that I can say really brings a completely new feel to the roguelike genre.  More in line with newer roguelikes, it is an easy to pick up, hard to master game with the freedom to tackle it how you please. The side-scrolling aspect of it keeps you on your toes and constantly vigilant. You're forced to move a quick pace to outrun the darkness, but are still given the ability to search for loot at as much leisure that can be allowed. In a way, this really brings the right level of tension and speed to the game. Not to mention the music. It really caught me off guard and I found myself humming many of the songs.   In summation, if you're looking for a new game to add to your collection this should be a prime candidate. The playthroughs are quick, but extremely fun. At three dollars, saying this is a steal is an understatement.

One Way Heroics is a fun and easy to understand approach to RPG rogue-likes with features to help the player extend his own gameplay from a single playthrough.  We choose from a variety of classes with pickable perks and go on a random adventure. Encountered by enemies and time itself, we wander across endless open plains and underneath mountain ranges, find dungeons with lots of danger and treasure, find cities to sell our useless stuff to NPCs and head further east. This gameplay routine might sound boring and stale but is actuallly a really fun activity the more you play.  The charm lies in the different classes and the different approach of each class. You can 'level up' your class globally in a way and earn Hero points at the end of each game (regardless of victory or death) and put these points to good use by buying additional perks or classes and more slots of a globally shared item storage that all your future characters have access to. Give yourself a headstart if you start to struggle.  My current playtime/bought-price ratio: 4hours > 0.75$ Rogue-like Quarter-diminisher: 4hours*0.25 End-result: 1 > 0.75$  tl;tr  This game is worth its sale price so do buy it if you find it for under a dollar. For this game will redeem itself by the playtime it offers.  Tiny tips:  >press the 'c' button to focus your attack panel because you can actually hit all of your eight adjacent panels >use it for a planned sideway walk because pressing two arrow buttons simultaneous sounds pretty rough if one wrong move can end your game if you accidentally find yourself in a predicament. >Infact, you can play this game entirely with just your arrow buttons and the 'Y','X' and 'C' button. Maximum Comfy.

Short answer: Reccomended for completionists, peopel who love NG+, and achievement hunters. If you like to complete a game and put it away, your experience may be lacking.    This review is somewhat late, as I beat it several months ago. It only took me about 4-6 playthroughs if I remember right. I think I only unlocked 2 additional classes and barely any of the other content, as I was able to 'win' through the luck of the RNG. I am someone who does not mind restarting games over and over due to dying and learning, but I can't say I like replaying a game once I've beat it.  One Way Heroics has fairly standard roguelike combat which I got the hang of fairly easily having played other games. The darkness adds an additional layer to this, almost making it like chess - you have to be able to plan your moves several steps ahead, taking into account each enemy's movement speed, movement patterns, item locations, and whether you might get trapped by the terrain. This can all be done fairly rapidly in most areas outside towns and dungeons. The game, being a rogelike, has a decent amount of teaching through experience and playthroughs.  The big big big gripe I have with the game, and is the primary reason I wish I could give a 'mixed' rating? I managed to kill the dark lord before I think I should have been able to. I discovered one of the special artifact items and managed to fight him inside a town. Just a single artifact, my level wasn't that high. I truly expected him to be harder. Then I expected that to not be all and for the devs to pull a 'Disc 1 final boss' on me. But no, the Big Bad of the game can be defeated by simply holeing up in an inn with a single artifact weapon and blowing all your items and special abilities. I had no longer felt a real desire to play it afterwards.  However, this is my personal taste. While I find the idea of NG+ and completing a game many many times fairly dull (in most cases) for those people who DO like that sort of gameplay, this is a decent offering. I didn't encounter many, if any bugs in my playing, and the visuals are uniformly presented with nothing that seemed out of place. Worth the money for that kind of player, and having gotten it on sale and with the addition of trading cards I can't say it wasn't worth the 69 cents I paid for it, if not more.

One of the best and most addictive indie rogue-like RPGs I ever played. Personally this is my favorite!   Unique idea of going 'One Way' to the right of the screen, without turning back or you will be consumed by the 'Darkness' and die. The goal is to defeat the 'Demon Lord', defeat the 'Darkness Dragon' or reach the 'End of the World' at 2000 kilometers.    Many different and exciting quests/endings along with strong storytelling   Various difficulty settings and random map generation, which increases the replay value   It has perma-death, but you can still save your game   Pick up and deposit items from other playthroughs (dimensional vault)   Lots of items, classes, perks and NPCs to unlock   Leveling up system including different affected stats   simple fast paced/turn-based combat and class specific skills   Lots of depth, still simple and quick learning curve   J-RPG menus & comedy   towns with merchants and other NPCs   dungeons with monsters and loot   online feature which shows other players current progression in their world (live)   online events/quests with specific rules, which change every day   manually input seed to replay a world   Nice Anime 'RPG-Maker'-like graphics. If it´s made by RPG-Maker, I would say it´s the most possible content you can get out of that engine, so far.  Great fitting soundtrack :)    Highly recommended and totally worth the money =P

This game is brutal no matter what difficulty you pick, in best possible way as a rogue-like. It has a VERY surprising amount of depth for a game that is by default played on a resolution of about a smart phone (what you see in the screenshots is what you get, and full-screening it does not help its prettiness!). Graphics-wise, it's incredibly indie -- see the character 'portraits' in the bottom left corner that seem to be sketches made a bored developer, especially Swordmaster Class C for a laugh.  If you get this game, it's for its gameplay, which does one thing, but does it really, really well. The turn-based gameplay with a constant timer and emphasis on movement will make it incredibly addicting for old-time Rogue-like players, as experience points (read: monsters to farm) and treasure may be within arm's reach but inaccessible due to the choices you have to make. The item appraisal system makes every item a mystery and makes even a new starting sword drop a desired reward, as durability constantly counts down with few ways to repair items and replenish supplies. Even when you're on top of the world, you'll feel pressured and challenged by item weights and inventory limits, decreasing energy and stamina, and other factors to encourage you to weigh risk and reward ('how long should I wear this Training Bracelet, which cripples my stats for more experience?') to get ready for the next area.  The 'hidden' parts of the game are by far the most enticing. You simply have to go out and find out for yourself how to get access to things like Party Members, Force powers (spells), the Dark Brotherhood, Hidden Elf Villages, Goddess Statues, and Key of Seals and their associated doors. After each death or victory, the progression system encourages trial and error, mixing and matching unlockable classes and perks with rotating featured Dimensions and allowing players to access the Dimensional Vault to carry over a limited number of items. The game is well-supported outside of a playthrough with a replay system, a hall of fame for each dimension and for your overall profile, and, of course, the different daily Dimensions featured. It does not hold your hand after kicking you out of the castle with a fairy of questionable use, explaining only the most basic and necessary mechanics until you recruit party members: you have to go out and discover it for yourself, since at a base level the game is so simple! Even the limited story and simple humor is fun to discover, especially as more party-member-specific endings are unlocked.  One of the best games on Steam under $5, and amongst my favorite Rogue-likes; highly, highly recommend.

Across all dimensions, the only constant is Darkness! A procedurally generated RPG-roguelike journey across the multiverse!  In One Way Heroics, you take on the role of an intrepid adventurer who must travel across the land and face the Demon Lord before a mysterious darkness engulfs everything.  Darkness always approaches from the left, and with each movement, attack and action you take, the darkness creeps ever closer. Forced to run right, you'll encounter any number of monsters, allies, thieves and shops on your desperate journey to stop the end of everything.  The good news is that you don't just have access to one world. You have access to all of them. Born with the mysterious power to travel to other dimensions, you can choose which dimension you wish to travel to in order to get to the Demon Lord.  Dimensions vary based on their name. One might be full of lush forest landscapes full of adorable animals and cunning thieves, while another might be full of corrupted hellscapes infested with demons. You might find likeminded heroes willing to journey with you, or you might meet no one and be forced to venture into the unknown alone.  Like a dimension you previously visited? Simply input the name at the Dimensional selection screen before you begin your journey. Want to try your luck with a random dimension? Type any word that pops into your head, and watch as One Way Heroics builds you a world based on the name you chose.  Infinite permutations. Infinite worlds. Infinite adventure.

Quite possibly one of my favorite Roguelikes to date. Multiple classes, perks, partners, unlockables, difficulties and randomly generated worlds makes each runthrough an experience full of experimentation and discovery. The simplistic yet charming artstyle works well with the turn-based style gameplay as well and with the shadows constantly chasing your character down, you have to carefully strategize and choose your moves wisely in order to survive while preparing for the troubles ahead.  The only disappointing part is the limited amount of unlockables (easily obtainable by about 3 hours of play), but One Way Heroics makes up for this with the large amount of replayability.   Overall, with the massive amount of replayability, class/perk combinations, cheesy humor, and daily seeds, I can easily see myself coming back to this game even years after its release.

One Way Heroics has a certain whimsical charm to it, and not just with its 8-bit graphics. The soundtrack is absolutely   amazing . Every time I open this game, I stop for about 10 minutes just to listen to the title screen's music. The mechanics of the game are fantastic, despite the somewhat steep learning curve, and is simplistic enough for a casual session but is also surprisingly deep enough for a major time investment.   The story isn't exactly an enchanting epic, but you can do with it as you like. Either fill in for them or just ignore it. Some great darkness is consuming the world, which is the left most part of the screen, and you have to escape that darkness by going to the right, hence the title of the game. Along the way, you'll encounter beasts, animals, dungeons, and dodgy terrain; all of which you must face in order to prepare for the advent of the Demon Lord.  Your journey is defined by you. It can turn from a simple stroll across the meadow to a desperate struggle to survive. It can be simple, it can be deep. Overall, One Way Heroics is a great adventure RPG that can't hurt your wallet.

If you're looking for an arcade-depth roguelike, you've found it! While it lacks the depth and intricacies of the pure breeds of the genre, such as the classic ADOM or more recent Dungeons of Dredmor, this game delivers familiar mechanics in a session you can begin AND win within an hour. The gimmick is simple, darkness is literally spreading across the land from the left side of the screen to the right, forcing you to run from it at all times. Every encounter or location you try to explore is an opportunity cost, and time is precious. However, failure to probe enough of the world will result in insufficient necessary medical supplies or a total lack of gear in time for the boss fight, should you survive long enough to hike to it. It follows a lot of the genre's standards, such as the world not moving until you take your actions, but since it is more simplistic, it adds something most roguelikes cannot do comfortably: 360 Controller support. Another fun feature is the world is generated by a key phrase, so you can replay a particular map, or seed a new one by letting your cat walk across your keyboard.

Part roguelike, part JRPG, One Way Heroics is an hybrid game that should please many people.  The game tasks you to keep moving forward (from left to right) in a world that is randomly generated, to become stronger and stronger, until you're finally able to save the world by defeating the Evil Lord responsible for the Darkness invading from the left.  But contrary to pure roguelikes, a failure doesn't mean you lose everything : when you finish a game (regardless of whether it was a success or not), you can save some items from your inventory into a 'Dimensional Vault'. The vault allow your next heroes to grab the items from them, and thus start a new game with powerful equipments right from the start. With this system, you can soon have starting heroes that are extremely powerful.  Moreover, since this is an hybrid JRPG, there is a lot more story in this game than there is in a typical roguelike. During each of your travels, you may find some new locations or characters, and this will help you better understand what is exactly happening to the world, as well as unlocking new places, storylines and endings. This helps alleviates one of the problems of roguelikes which is that they sometimes feel like you're doing the same thing over and over again.  The gameplay itself is nice, with many items, skills, and classes that allow for different approaches to combat. It's turn-based, with positioning being an important part of the combat system. If you're lucky, you might later be able to expand your party, and have companions help you on your quests, which add more tactical options. Once again, this is a nice difference to classic roguelikes where you're usually all alone all the time.  Another good point for the game is that it should please a large number of RPG or roguelike fans. It has 4 different difficulty levels and you also have the option to turn off the Dimensional Vault as you wish. This mean that casual players will enjoy being able to finish the game on Easy and Normal, while Roguelike veterans will get the challenge they are looking for by playing harder difficulties, without the help of the vault.  On the whole, I really enjoy One Way Heroics. It offers me some interesting challenges, but somehow, it also feel like a relaxing game, because you're all alone in the vast open country (contrary to many roguelikes who prefer claustrophobic dungeons). It's a very nice game to both unwind, and also get my brain working hard, depending on which difficulty i play on. And i keep coming back to it, because there is a lot of secrets that i have yet to find and classes i have yet to finish the game with.

One Way Heroics is a turn-based roguelike game. After the character creation and a bit of customisation you are dropped into a randomly generated world with death coming for you from the left side of the screen and adventure, loot and almost certain death waiting for you on the right. Every time you move, fight, use an object or talk, the world moves on: enemies act and the darkness comes a little bit closer, forcing you to plan your next moves well. Do you want to try going for that treasure chest? Kill that enemy? Explore that building? Maybe talk to a merchant somewhere else on the screen? You are very unlikely to be able to do everything. Luckily, you can generally move a bit faster than the darkness, so even if you let it come close, you will be able to outrun it for a bit again, provided you don't waste too much time for a bit. If you make it far enough, a boss will show up and you can win the game... or die trying.   Due to the random map generation, the difficulty of the game will vary greatly from cakewalk to trying to break a wall with your head. However, after each round you are allowed to buy new perks, unlock other classes or upgrade your dimensional vault, a storage that allows you to transfer things into your next round - great for storing that overpowered weapon you found right before darkness caught up to you.   Not a game you will end up sacrificing your social life to, but a great deal of fun to have in little bursts. It's quick to pick up, the rounds are short and refreshing, and afterwards you will still have a fair amount of the day left to spend on studying, working or even socialising if that's what floats your boat.

One Way Heroics has a certain whimsical charm to it, and not just with its 8-bit graphics. The soundtrack is absolutely   amazing . The mechanics of the game are fantastic, despite the somewhat steep learning curve, and is simplistic enough for a casual session but is also surprisingly deep enough for a major time investment.   The story isn't exactly an enchanting epic, but you can do with it as you like. Either fill in for them or just ignore it. Some great darkness is consuming the world, which is the left most part of the screen, and you have to escape that darkness by going to the right, hence the title of the game. Along the way, you'll encounter beasts, animals, dungeons, and dodgy terrain; all of which you must face in order to prepare for the advent of the Demon Lord.  Your journey is defined by you. It can turn from a simple stroll across the meadow to a desperate struggle to survive. It can be simple, it can be deep. Overall, One Way Heroics is a great adventure RPG that can't hurt your wallet.

For anyone who's a fan of roguelikes, this game is right up your alley. It's actually got a bit of personality above and beyond many roguelikes that are out there, and the pixel graphics really add charm, if they're your style.  Progression is quick, and every death seems to lead to either a new bit of knowledge, or extra strength for the next run. It also provides a fine amount of replay, incorporating daily realms and other online elements, so if you're looking for another run on a new class, or a new level of challenge, the game is constantly giving you new stuff to contend with.  For whatever reason, the game won't let me play in fullscreen, despite my best efforts to do so, but that's really just a tiny complaint. Same thing for the keyboard-only controls, which thankfully are very simple and intuitive. All in all, this game provides a remarkable amount of content for under five bucks, and even if it was ten, I'd heartily recommend it to roguelike fans.  Final rating: 8/10

A great, simple and entertaing Rogue-like rpg with a twist. This games offers engaging sessions of rogue-like adventuring , while being able to persistently unlock new features such as classes, perks and more. While its gameplay mechanics are pretty simple, there are many combinations of randomly-generated equipment, skills and events for you character. Each class is a bit different in terms of gameplay so you'll probably be wanting to try out every available combination of class+perks more than once. The gameplay gets repetitive after a while so I doubt anyone would be playing it 24/7 nonstop, but nevertheless it's a good experience for its price.   One of the few features that caught my eye was a 'Daily Online Challenge' or 'Campaign Dimensions'. Each day the seed is generated for a world where everyone who plays a game can join. While it's impossible to interact directly with other players you can encounter the ghosts of defeated players and read the recent chat logs of other adventurers, how much time they have spent, who killed them and what items they have obtained in this world.  Same with the 'online' adventures, new adventures with different conditions are also generated daily. E.g. The ones where you can recruit a powerful ally, or a world covered in constant darkness, limiting your vision.  9/10 will play again.

I'm sure there will be drawbacks in there somewhere, and i usually wait to review a game until i've given it a more thorough playthrough, but it's so solid already, and reminded me so much of what i  thought  i was going to get from Desktop Disappointments that i had to say something. And for only $10 with DLC.  It's like... when you see this girl, and she looks really good on paper, and everyone (including her) is telling you how great she is. With the Mystery Chronicle version of OWH adding some divisive choices into the game, it made me appreciate the relative simplicity of OWH a lot. It's just you, the monsters, your companions, a Demon Lord, 1000km+ of neverending, randomly generated road ahead of you, and a wall of black death behind you.   There's nothing really like it (other than itself) and it's pretty much one of, if not, THE best 'coffeebreak roguelikes' out there that's actually an honest-to-God ROGUELIKE. There are guns, but no twinstick shooting. Skills, but no cooldowns. Time, but not real-time. It feels good to see something actually carry the spirit of Rogue while doing its own thing without taking it into an entirely different genre.  So get it. This and it's expansion pack OWH+ goes on sale for about $2 dollars every sale. I don't know why you are still reading this and not going out to slay an evil lord, stop a death wall, and (maybe) save a cleric with dog-ears life?
It's Jordin Sparks- One Step At A Time, made into a video game.

There is a TL:DR  If you grab this game for less than $1 then it is very much worth it. I actually REALLY like the game and the simplicity of combat but boy oh howdy is it a very shallow experience. Aside from tiny modifiers and higher difficulties this is a very easy game to beat once you figure out how not to die to the moving wall of darkness.  There are 2 types of rogue like games. The first type you actually progress your character accross playthroughs (Dead Rising, Rogue Legacy) where you get your sense of accomplishment despite not beating the game.  The other type consists of losing literally everything stat and possession and see if you roll the dice better this time around. Thats much harder to remain satisfying since from a stat angle you can't tell who has 80 hours of play time and who has 5 hours. So why invest the additional 75 hours?  This game is the latter, sure certain games can pull it off like Faster then Light because you unlock ways that alter the game in a dramatic way that getting those unlocks feels worth it even if you lose. This game has a few different classes but they control and play almost identically and their bonuses would only be noticed if this game was in the former catagory. It wouldn't be hard either, you remove weapon degredation (since you can save items between playthroughs) and allow perminent base stat increases using the levels you gain in playthrough as currency. Make this playthrough harder so that future ones will be easier sort of deal, they already have something like that but it only applies to the current playthrough  TL:DR this game is very much worth if you're buying it for literal cents on the dollar. It goes on sale frequently

The music is ear-bleedingly bad and manages to sound repetitive without actually being repetitive. Why would the 'artist' put their name on this?   The sounds in general are terribad. It is trying to pay homage to the 8 bit games of NES and the like, but it manages to actually be the same quality, only more shrill. Paying homage does not mean trying to literally copy the original, and then amp up the worst aspects.  There are 3 available resolutions. None are wide screen. One is so small that my phone actually has a larger screen. Terrible.  The resolution in general is very poor. Again, paying homage does not mean turning the negative aspects of something up to 11.   There are numerous interface issues. EG, why doesn't moving into an enemy attack them?   Overall, I cannot recommend this. It's an interesting idea done poorly.
